Award.AwardTitle: Academic Leadership for Women in Engineering
Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal # 1143535
Title: Academic Leadership for Women in Engineering
Principal Investigator: Peter Finn
The Society of Women in Engineering

Proposal Summary:
The Society of Women Engineers (SWE) is committed to the achievement and success of all women in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM). An important segment of SWE?s membership consists of women in academia. Since retention and promotion of women in academia, especially within engineering disciplines continues to be a significant challenge, this workshop will assist faculty to acquire essential leadership and management skills. Senior women mentors will share their experiences with the participants during this workshop. The proposed workshop will offer executive leadership opportunities and key skills that will support career advancement for women academics in engineering. Participants will be encouraged to pursue the full diversity of roles within their organizations that offer opportunities for leadership. The workshop will be hosted in October 13-15, 2011 at SWE?s annual conference, WE11, in Chicago, IL.
In addition, participants will learn sound practices in advancement in academia and develop opportunities and mechanisms for networking across institutions. Specific objectives of the workshop are:
? Increase the number of women in academic leadership positions
? Provide key practices and information that will accelerate and enhance the success of women in academic leadership positions
? Cultivate a network of practice for women engineering faculty leaders
? Develop mentor relationships that benefit women engineering faculty who are seeking leadership roles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Society of Women Engineers (SWE), founded in 1950, is a 501 (c) (3) not-for-profit educational and service organization. SWE is the driving force that establishes engineering as a highly desirable career aspiration for women. SWE empowers women to succeed and advance in those aspirations and be recognized for their life-changing contributions and achievements as engineers and leaders.

With more than 60 years of developing and encouraging women engineers and more specifically as part of SWE's ongoing commitment to women academic leaders in STEM, SWE developed and hosted a workshop entitled Academic Leadership for Women in Engineering (ALWE). The workshop was held October 14 – 15, 2011 at SWE's annual conference in Chicago, WE11. The workshop was attended by 32 women faculty representing a diverse group of institutions and backgrounds.

There is a paucity of national leadership programs that focus on women faculty.  Due to this need SWE developed and hosted the ALWE workshop. Participants at the workshop discussed sound practices in advancement in academia while also creating opportunities and mechanisms for networking across institutions. The goal of this project was to provide faculty women with key skills and knowledge that will support their career advancement. The majority of workshop participants held tenured positions at their universities and came to the workshop with some formal and informal leadership experience at their university. SWE facilitated virtual interaction between participants prior to the workshop by launching an online social network site. The networking site allowed for workshop instructors to post articles and discussion questions. This helped frame some of the discussions when participants convened in Chicago for two days. This also gave workshop participants an opportunity to introduce themselves and what they recognized as their needed areas of growth as leaders.

The workshop began with a keynote presentation by Dr. Kristina Johnson, former U.S. undersecretary of energy, who discussed the various leadership roles she has held and the challenges of leading within a university. After the keynote, the workshop instructors focused on developing leadership capacity and emotional intelligence, the business of universities, negotiation strategies for women leaders, and career planning tools.  Additionally, the project provided a template for future workshops and learning interventions devoted do the advancement of women in academia, specifically in the area of engineering.

At the end of each day participants were asked to provide feedback on the speakers and content of the workshop.  Overall the feedback from both days was extremely positive and many of the participants felt that the content was very applicable to their development as leaders within the context of academia. Many participants expressed interest in learning more about the business of universities and some were also interested in a "more frank" discussion on the work/life balance issues that face women faculty.

In the 30-60 day follow-up survey, many participants had noted the value of networking with other women faculty and being able to share some best practices in leadership. Most indicated that they had been able to apply the workshop content to their current role. There was an apparent theme among respondents that in future workshops there be more focus on the business of university and negotiation. This is a topic where most participants noted they receive little to no training or guidance.

The workshop was successful in helping participants create their plan for developing a leadership skill-set and perspective on strategies for advancement. Based on the evaluation of the workshop, SWE should further expand its leadership training program for members and partners in academia. There is an apparent lack of leadership and management training for engineering faculty and faculty leaders (e.g., department chairs) and certainly a need for more workshops that SWE hosted.

With more women leaders within university engineering schools, we can ultimately attract more women and promote diversity at all levels and professions within engineering. Projections on the US workforce needs, specifically in STEM, in the next decade suggest a need to tap all available resources and the most obvious resource for US engineering is the underrepresented groups – including women and minorities. Women and minorities do not see engineering as an opportunity because often the “face” of engineering does not look like them.
